Package edu.mit.csail.medg.csv2mysql

Class RangeTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.mit.csail.medg.csv2mysql.RangeTree
  • public class RangeTree
extends java.lang.Object
    A RangeTree is a compact representation of a set of ordered but possibly non-contiguous values. It maintains an ordered tree of nodes, each of which represents a non-overlapping and non-contiguous set of values, which are updated any time a new element is added. To get a compact representation, we need a dense set of values so that we can tell when two ranges meet and can therefore be merged. This is true for integers, but not strings or floating point values. Because in Csv2Mysql, these are used to store BigInteger values, we define them as specific to that type rather than generically. To make a generic version would require that the stored type support equal and adding/subtracting one, as well as ordering. Adding a new value to a RangeTree does one of the following:
    1. If the value is already present, return false.
    2. If the value is less than the low end of the lowest range, then
      • If it is one less, extend that range,
      • Otherwise, add a new range for that value.
    3. If the value falls between two ranges, then
      • If it is one greater than the top of the range below, extend that,
      • If it is one less than the range above, extend that,
      • Otherwise, add a new range for that value.
    Then, if the two ranges now meet, merge them.

    We represent the RangeTree as a TreeMap in which each entry has as its key the low end of a range and as its value the high end. Possible cases of where a new value can fit into existing ranges: 

           [flr        ]       [ceil       ]
             x
                           x
                    x
                          x
                       x

    We use a TreeMap to implement a range element, where the key is the lowest value of the range and the value is the highest.
    Author:
    psz@mit.edu
